title: Manage certificates
content:
This document gives an overview of the certificates required for secure communications between the various components of the suite. It also describes how to check the validity and how to renew an expired certificate.

Certificate configuration architectures

You can choose any of the following architectures for certificate configuration.

Direct access without an external load balancer

This configuration enables direct access to the suite without an external load balancer configured. The certificate configured between the user and the suite can be one of the following types.

  • CA certificate
  • Self-signed certificate

Access through an external load balancer

This configuration enables access through external load balance using the following certificate configuration:

  • The certificate configured between the user and load balancer is a CA certificate.
  • The certificate configured between the load balancer and suite components can be one of the following types.
    • CA certificate - Recommended
    • Self-signed certificate - Not recommended

How to check the validity and renew certificates

The table below gives instructions on how to check the validity of the certificates shown in the diagram of the recommended setup.

In the table below, Service Management refers to the OpenText Service Management application.
Number Interface Certificate Command to check the validity and the document link for renewal

User->Load Balancer

Integrations->Load Balancer

 External Load Balacer

# in command line:
openssl s_client -showcerts -connect <FQDN>:443 |  openssl x509 -noout -dates | grep notAfter

Refer to the load balancer document for certificate renewal instructions.

Load Balancer - Service Management

 Service Management ingress: (signed by custom CA or self-signed by MF RE CA)

# for port 443
kubectl get secret nginx-default-secret -n $(kubectl get ns | grep itsma | cut -f1 -d " ") -o=jsonpath='{.data.tls\.crt}' | base64 -d | openssl x509 -noout -dates | grep notAfter
For a helm-based environment, you can find the certificate in the values.yaml section nginx-> nginx-> tls ->cert, which is in base64 format. 

This certificate may be automatically renewed during an upgrade for a self-signed certificate. 

For manual renewal of the certificates, see Renew OMT ingress/Suite ingress certificates
 

Load Balancer - OMT  application

 OMT ingress: (signed by custom CA or self-signed by MF RE CA)
 

N/A for helm-based environment.
# for port 3000

kubectl get secret nginx-frontend-secret -n core -o=jsonpath='{.data.tls\.crt}' | base64 -d | openssl x509 -noout -dates | grep notAfter

# for port 5443

kubectl get secret nginx-default-secret -n core -o=jsonpath='{.data.tls\.crt}' | base64 -d | openssl x509 -noout -dates | grep notAfter

This certificate may be automatically renewed during an upgrade for a self-signed certificate. 

For manual renewal of the certificates, see Renew OMT ingress/Suite ingress certificates.

Load Balancer - SAML/IDM

 IDM/SAML: (self-signed)
 

See Check the validity of the IdM SAML SSO certificate and Renew the IdM SAML SSO certificate

OMT application - OMT application

 OMT application: (self-signed by MF OMT RIC CA)
 

# For embedded kubernetes, same as kubernetes cluster certificates in kube-status.sh
# For managed kubernetes 

kubectl exec -it `kubectl get po -n core | grep idm | head -n 1 | cut -f1 -d " "` -n core -c idm -- cat /var/run/secrets/boostport.com/server.crt | openssl x509 -noout -dates | grep notAfter

This certificate is automatically renewed.

For manual renewal of the certificates, see Renew OMT/Suite certificates.

Embedded Kubernetes  cluster

 Embedded Kubernetes  cluster (Self-signed by  MF OMT RIC CA)
 

./kube-status.sh Check "Kubernetes server certificate expiration date"

This certificate is automatically renewed during an upgrade.

For manual renewal of the certificates, see Renew OMT/Suite certificates.

There is no need to check the validity of the certificate.

Service Management - UD/UCMDB

UD/UCMDB ingress: 

(Signed by custom CA or self-signed by MF RE CA)
 

kubectl get secret nginx-default-secret -n <UD/UCMDB namespace> -o=jsonpath='{.data.tls\.crt}' | base64 -d | openssl x509 -noout -dates | grep notAfter
 

For manual renewal of the certificates, see Renew OMT ingress/Suite ingress certificates, and use your UD/UCMDB namespace for the commands.

Service Management - PostgresSQL
Postgres server certificate

cat $PGDATA/server.crt | openssl x509 -noout -dates | grep notAfter
 

Follow the Postgres vendor/AWS/GCP document to renew the certificates, as long as the setup is correct, it's not required to replace the certificates in the suite trust store. Otherwise, follow Enable SSL connections to external PostgreSQL after suite installation.

For helm-based environment, you can find the certificate in the values.yaml section database -> caCertificates -> pg_ca.crt, which is in base64 format.

Troubleshooting certificate issues

Symptom in the browser Symptom in the client Workaround
1 The browser reports the website is not secure. The client reports being unable to find a valid certification path to the requested target.
 		 Add or renew the certificate in the load balancer and/or suite ingress and OMT ingress.
2 The browser works fine.
 		 The client reports being unable to find a valid certification path to the requested target.
 		 It's due to an incomplete certificate chain provided by the server; you need to renew the certificate on the server with server certificate + intermediate CA
3 The browser works fine.

The client works fine but the client trust-store renewal relies on the server certificate which is less than a year.

 It's due to an incomplete certificate chain provided by the server; you need to renew the certificate on the server with server certificate + intermediate CA
